Charles Babbage Signature.svg Charles Babbage,Royal SocietyFRS(IPAc-enˈbæbɪdʒ; 26 December 1791 18 October 1871) was an Englishpolymath.cite bookTerence WhalenEdgar Allan Poe and the masses: the political economy of literature in antebellum Americahttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20131999Princeton University Press978-0-691-00199-9254A mathematician, philosopher, inventor and mechanical engineer, Babbage is best remembered for originating the concept of a programmable computer.

Considered a "computer pioneerfather of the computer",cite bookHalacy, Daniel StephenCharles Babbage, Father of the Computer1970Crowell-Collier Press0-02-741370-5Babbage is credited with inventing the firstmechanical computerthat eventually led to more complex designs. His varied work in other fields has led him to be described as "pre-eminent" among the many polymaths of his century.

Parts of Babbage's uncompleted mechanisms are on display in theLondon Science Museum. In 1991, a perfectly functioningdifference enginewas constructed from Babbage's original plans. Built toengineering tolerancetolerancesachievable in the 19th century, the success of the finished engine indicated that Babbage's machine would have worked.
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Babbage's birthplace is disputed, but according to theOxford Dictionary of National Biographyhe was most likely born at 44 Crosby Row,Walworth Road, London, England.cite ODNB962Babbage, CharlesDoronSwadeAblue plaqueon the junction of Larcom Street and Walworth Road commemorates the event.openplaque1140

His date of birth was given in his obituary inThe Timesas 26 December 1792; but then a nephew wrote to say that Babbage was born one year earlier, in 1791. The parish register of St. Mary'sNewington, London, shows that Babbage wasBaptismbaptisedon 6 January 1792, supporting a birth year of 1791.harvnbHyman19825cite bookMoseleyMabothIrascible Genius, The Life of Charles BabbageHenry RegneryChicago196429http://books.google.com.au/books?idharvcite news[[s:The Times/The Late Mr. Charles Babbage, F.R.S.|The Late Mr. Charles Babbage, F.R.S]]The TimesUKFile:Charles Babbage 1860.jpgthumbright''The Illustrated London News'' (4 November 1871).cite bookHookDiana H.Jeremy M. NormanMichael R. WilliamsOrigins of cyberspace: a library on the history of computing, networking, and telecommunicationsNorman Publishing2002161, 165http://books.google.com/?id0-930405-85-4Babbage was one of four children of Benjamin Babbage and Betsy Plumleigh Teape. His father was a banking partner ofWilliam Praedin founding Praed's & Co. ofFleet Street, London, in 1801.cite webMembers Constituencies Parliaments Surveyshttp://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1790-1820/member/praed-william-1747-1833''Praed, William (1747–1833), of Tyringham, Bucks. and Trevethoe, nr. St. Ives, Cornw.''Historyofparliamentonline.org2014-06-07In 1808, the Babbage family moved into the old Rowdens house inTeignmouthEast Teignmouth. Around the age of eight Babbage was sent to a country school inAlphington, DevonAlphingtonnear Exeter to recover from a life-threatening fever. For a short time he attendedKing Edward VI Community College#Grammar schoolKing Edward VI Grammar SchoolinTotnes, South Devon, but his health forced him back to private tutors for a time.harvnbMoseley196439

Babbage then joined the 30-student Holmwood academy, in Baker Street,Municipal Borough of EnfieldEnfield,Middlesex, under the Reverend Stephen Freeman. The academy had a library that prompted Babbage's love of mathematics. He studied with two more private tutors after leaving the academy. The first was a clergyman nearCambridge; through him Babbage encounteredCharles Simeonand his evangelical followers, but the tuition was not what he needed.cite bookAnthony HymanCharles Babbage: Pioneer Of The Computerhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20131 January 1985Princeton University Press978-0-691-02377-917He was brought home, to study at the Totnes school: this was at age 16 or 17.cite bookBruce CollierJames MacLachlanCharles Babbage: And the Engines of Perfectionhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 201328 September 2000Oxford University Press978-0-19-514287-711The second was an Oxford tutor, under whom Babbage reached a level in Classics sufficient to be accepted by Cambridge.
article.heading: At the University of Cambridge
article.paragraph: Babbage arrived atTrinity College, Cambridge, in October 1810.acadBBG810CBabbage, CharlesHe was already self-taught in some parts of contemporary mathematics;cite bookE. S. Leedham-GreenA Concise History of the University of Cambridgehttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 201326 September 1996Cambridge University Press978-0-521-43978-7142–he had read inRobert Woodhouse,Joseph Louis Lagrange, andMarie Agnesi. As a result, he was disappointed in the standard mathematical instruction available at Cambridge.

Babbage,John Herschel,George Peacock, and several other friends formed theAnalytical Societyin 1812; they were also close toEdward Ryan (barrister)Edward Ryan.Wilkes (2002)p.355As a student, Babbage was also a member of other societies such asThe Ghost Club, concerned with investigating supernatural phenomena, and the Extractors Club, dedicated to liberating its members from the madhouse, should any be committed to one.cite bookHofstadterDouglas R.Douglas Hofstadter[[Gödel, Escher, Bach: an Eternal Golden Braid]][[Penguin Books]]19792000726cite webCharles Babbage'S Computer Engineshttp://www.allsands.com/history/objects/history/objects/babbagecomputer_yy_gn.htm13 March 2012

In 1812 Babbage transferred toPeterhouse, Cambridge.He was the top mathematician there, but did not graduate with honours. He instead received a degree without examination in 1814. He had defended a thesis that was considered blasphemous in the preliminary public disputation; but it is not known whether this fact is related to his not sitting the examination.
article.heading: After Cambridge
article.paragraph: Considering only his reputation, Babbage quickly made progress. He lectured to theRoyal Institutionon astronomy in 1815, and was elected aFellow of the Royal Societyin 1816.cite bookJames EssingerJacquard's Web2007Oxford University Press978-0-19-280578-259 and 98After graduation, on the other hand, he applied for positions unsuccessfully, and had little in the way of career. In 1816 he was a candidate for a teaching job atHaileybury College; he had recommendations fromJames Ivory (mathematician)James IvoryandJohn Playfair, but lost out toHenry Walter (antiquary)Henry Walter.cite bookRaymond FloodAdrian RiceRobin WilsonMathematics in Victorian Britainhttp://books.google.com/books?id25 April 201329 September 2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-960139-4145In 1819, Babbage and Herschel visited Paris and theSociety of Arcueil, meeting leading French mathematicians and physicists.cite bookGeorge Green: Mathematician and Physicist, 1793–1841: The Background to His Life and Workhttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20132001SIAM978-0-89871-463-0255 note 19That year Babbage applied to be professor at theUniversity of Edinburgh, with the recommendation ofPierre Simon Laplace; the post went toWilliam Wallace (mathematician)William Wallace.cite bookRoger HahnPierre Simon Laplace: 1749 – 1827; a Determined Scientisthttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20132005Harvard University Press978-0-674-01892-1295 note 34cite ODNB28545Wallace, WilliamMariaPantekicite bookThe Edinburgh magazine, and literary miscellany, a new series of The Scots magazinehttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20131819369

With Herschel, Babbage worked on the electrodynamics ofArago's rotations, publishing in 1825. Their explanations were only transitional, being picked up and broadened byMichael Faraday. The phenomena are now part of the theory ofeddy currents, and Babbage and Herschel missed some of the clues to unification ofelectromagnetic theory, staying close toAmpre's force law.cite bookL. Pearce WilliamsMichael Faraday1965Da Capo Press978-0-306-80299-7170–2

Babbage purchased the actuarial tables ofGeorge Barrett (actuary)George Barrett, who died in 1821 leaving unpublished work, and surveyed the field in 1826 inComparative View of the Various Institutions for the Assurance of Lives.cite ODNB1523Barrett, GeorgeRobertBrownThis interest followed a project to set up an insurance company, prompted byFrancis Bailyand mooted in 1824, but not carried out.cite bookBruce CollierJames MacLachlanCharles Babbage: And the Engines of Perfectionhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 201328 September 2000Oxford University Press978-0-19-514287-729–30Babbage did calculate actuarial tables for that scheme, usingEquitable Societymortality data from 1762 onwards.cite bookAnthony HymanCharles Babbage: Pioneer Of The Computerhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20131 January 1985Princeton University Press978-0-691-02377-959

During this whole period Babbage depended awkwardly on his father's support, given his father's attitude to his early marriage, of 1814: he and Edward Ryan wedded the Whitmore sisters. He made a home inMarylebonein London, and founded a large family.cite bookJamesRemarkable Engineershttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 2013Cambridge University Press978-1-139-48625-545On his father's death in 1827, Babbage inherited a large estate (value around 100,000), making him independently wealthy.After his wife's death in the same year he spent time travelling. In Italy he metLeopold II, Grand Duke of Tuscany, foreshadowing a later visit to Piedmont.In April 1828 he was in Rome, and relying on Herschel to manage the difference engine project, when he heard that he had become professor at Cambridge, a position he had three times failed to obtain (in 1820, 1823 and 1826).cite bookKevin C. KnoxFrom Newton to Hawking: A History of Cambridge University's Lucasian Professors of Mathematicshttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20136 November 2003Cambridge University Press978-0-521-66310-6242 and 258–72
article.heading: Astronomical Society
article.paragraph: Babbage was instrumental in founding theAstronomical Societyin 1820. Its initial aims were to reduce astronomical calculations to a more standard form, and to circulate data.cite bookMartin Campbell-KellyThe History of Mathematical Tables: From Sumer to Spreadsheetshttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20132 October 2003Oxford University Press978-0-19-850841-08These directions were closely connected with Babbage's ideas on computation, and in 1824 he won itsGold Medal of the Royal Astronomical SocietyGold Medal, cited "for his invention of an engine for calculating mathematical and astronomical tables".

Babbage's motivation to overcome errors in tables by mechanisation has been a commonplace sinceDionysius Lardnerwrote about it in 1834 in theEdinburgh Review(under Babbage's guidance).cite bookRaymond FloodAdrian RiceRobin WilsonMathematics in Victorian Britainhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 201329 September 2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-162794-134cite bookHarro MaasWilliam Stanley Jevons and the Making of Modern Economicshttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 20134 April 2005Cambridge University Press978-0-521-82712-6201The context of these developments is still debated. Babbage's own account of the origin of the difference engine begins with the Astronomical Society's wish to improveThe Nautical Almanac. Babbage and Herschel were asked to oversee a trial project, to recalculate some part of those tables. With the results to hand, discrepancies were found. This was in 1821 or 1822, and was the occasion on which Babbage formulated his idea for mechanical computation.cite bookM. Norton WiseThe values of precisionhttp://books.google.com/books?id25 April 201317 March 1997Princeton University Press978-0-691-01601-6320The issue of theNautical Almanacis now described as a legacy of a polarisation in British science caused by attitudes toSir Joseph Banks, who had died in 1820.cite bookEleanor RobsonJacqueline StedallThe Oxford Handbook of the History of Mathematicshttp://books.google.com/books?id25 April 201318 December 2008Oxford University Press978-0-19-160744-8xxxivFile:Difference engine plate 1853.jpgthumbA portion of the difference engineBabbage studied the requirements to establish a modernpostal system, with his friendThomas Frederick Colby, concluding there should be a uniform rate that was put into effect with the introduction of theUniform Fourpenny Postsupplanted by theUniform Penny Postcite bookAnthony HymanCharles Babbage: Pioneer Of The Computerhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20131 January 1985Princeton University Press978-0-691-02377-9115in 1839 and 1840. Colby was another of the founding group of the Society.cite bookAnthony HymanCharles Babbage: Pioneer Of The Computerhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20131 January 1985Princeton University Press978-0-691-02377-945He was also in charge of theSurvey of Ireland. Herschel and Babbage were present at a celebrated operation of that survey, the remeasuring of theLough Foylebaseline.cite bookRoyal Institution of Great BritainProceedingshttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20131858518
article.heading: British Lagrangian School
article.paragraph: The Analytical Society had initially been no more than an undergraduate provocation. During this period it had some more substantial achievements. In 1816 Babbage, Herschel and Peacock published a translation from French of the lectures ofSylvestre Lacroix, which was then the state-of-the-art calculus textbook.cite bookConstructing a Bridge: An Exploration of Engineering Culture, Design, and Research in Nineteenth-century France and Americahttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20131997MIT Press978-0-262-11217-8110

Reference to Lagrange in calculus terms marks out the application of what are now calledformal power series. British mathematicians had used them from about 1730 to 1760. As re-introduced, they were not simply applied as notations indifferential calculus. They opened up the fields offunctional equations(including thedifference equationsfundamental to the difference engine) and operator (D-module) methods fordifferential equations. The analogy of difference and differential equations was notationally changing to D, as a "finite" difference becomes "infinitesimal". These symbolic directions became popular, asoperational calculus, and pushed to the point of diminishing returns. The(, )-definition of limitCauchy concept of limitwas kept at bay.cite book[[Niccolò Guicciardini]]The Development of Newtonian Calculus in Britain, 1700–1800http://books.google.com/books?id26 April 201313 November 2003Cambridge University Press978-0-521-52484-1138Woodhouse had already founded this second "British Lagrangian School" with its treatment ofTaylor seriesas formal.cite bookDov M. GabbayJohn WoodsBritish Logic in the Nineteenth Centuryhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 201310 March 2008Elsevier978-0-08-055701-4403–4

In this contextfunction compositionis complicated to express, because thechain ruleis not simply applied to second and higher derivatives. This matter was known to Woodhouse by 1803, who took fromLouis Franois Antoine Arbogastwhat is now calledFa di Bruno's formula(a misnomer). In essence it was known toAbraham De Moivre(1697). Herschel found the method impressive, Babbage knew of it, and it was later noted by Lovelace as compatible with the analytical engine.Craik pp. 1223.In the period to 1820 Babbage worked intensively on functional equations in general, and resisted both conventionalfinite differencesand Arbogast's approach (in which and D were related by the simple additive case of theexponential functionexponential map). But via Herschel he was influenced by Arbogast's ideas in the matter ofiterated functioniteration, i.e. composing a function with itself, possibly many times.Writing in a major paper on functional equations in thePhilosophical Transactions(1815/6), Babbage said his starting point was work ofGaspard Monge.cite bookJeremy J. GrayKaren Hunger ParshallEpisodes in the History of Modern Algebra (1800–1950)http://books.google.com/books?id26 April 201331 August 2011American Mathematical Soc.978-0-8218-7257-419
article.heading: Academic
article.paragraph: From 1828 to 1839 Babbage wasLucasian Professor of Mathematicsat Cambridge. Not a conventional residentuniversity dondon, and inattentive to teaching, he wrote three topical books during this period of his life. He was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of theAmerican Academy of Arts and Sciencesin 1832.cite webBook of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter Bhttp://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterB.pdfAmerican Academy of Arts and Sciences28 April 2011Babbage was out of sympathy with colleagues:George Biddell Airy, his predecessor as Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Trinity College, Cambridge,George Biddell Airy#Biographythought an issue should be made of his lack of interest in lecturing. Babbage planned to lecture in 1831 onpolitical economy. Babbage's reforming direction looked to see university education more inclusive, universities doing more for research, a broader syllabus and more interest in applications; butWilliam Whewellfound the programme unacceptable. A controversy Babbage had withRichard Jones (economist)Richard Joneslasted for six years.cite bookKevin C. KnoxFrom Newton to Hawking: A History of Cambridge University's Lucasian Professors of Mathematicshttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20136 November 2003Cambridge University Press978-0-521-66310-6284–5He never did give a lecture.ThoemmesBritish19CBabbage, Charles35

It was during this period that Babbage tried to enter politics.Simon Schafferwrites that his views of the 1830s includeddisestablishmentof theChurch of England, a broaderpolitical franchise, and inclusion of manufacturers as stakeholders.cite bookKevin C. KnoxFrom Newton to Hawking: A History of Cambridge University's Lucasian Professors of Mathematicshttp://books.google.com/books?id25 April 20136 November 2003Cambridge University Press978-0-521-66310-6243He twice stood for Parliament as a candidate for the borough ofFinsbury (UK Parliament constituency)Finsbury. In 1832 he came in third among five candidates, missing out by some 500 votes in the two-member constituency when two other reformist candidates,Thomas Wakleyand Christopher Temple, split the vote.cite webMembers Constituencies Parliaments Surveyshttp://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1820-1832/constituencies/middlesexhistoryofparliamentonline.org, ''Middlesex County 1820–1832''Historyofparliamentonline.org2014-06-07cite bookSylvanus UrbanThe Gentleman's Magazinehttp://books.google.com/books?id25 April 20131838659In his memoirs Babbage related how this election brought him the friendship ofSamuel Rogers: his brother Henry Rogers wished to support Babbage again, but died within days.cite bookCharles BabbagePassages from the life of a philosopherhttp://books.google.com/books?id1 May 20131864Longman, Green, Longman, Roberts, & Green190–1In 1834 Babbage finished last among four.cite bookCrowther, J. G.Scientific Types1968Barrie & RockliffLondon2660-248-99729-7cite bookHymanAnthonyCharles Babbage, Pioneer of the Computer1982Princeton University PressPrinceton, New Jersey82–70-691-08303-7harvharvnbMoseley1964120–1- Note some confusion as to the dates.
article.heading: "Declinarians", learned societies and the BAAS
article.paragraph: File:Babbage - Letter to sir Humphry Davy on the application of machinery to the purpose of calculating and printing mathematical tables, 1822 - 721620.tifthumb''Letter to sir Humphry Davy'', 1822Babbage now emerged as apolemicist. One of his biographers notes that all his books contain a "campaigning element". HisReflections on the Decline of Science and some of its Causes(1830) stands out, however, for its sharp attacks. It aimed to improve British science, and more particularly to oustDavies Gilbertas President of the Royal Society, which Babbage wished to reform.cite bookAnthony HymanCharles Babbage: Pioneer Of The Computerhttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20131 January 1985Princeton University Press978-0-691-02377-988It was written out of pique, when Babbage hoped to become the junior secretary of the Royal Society, as Herschel was the senior, but failed because of his antagonism toHumphry Davy.cite bookJamesRemarkable Engineershttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 2013Cambridge University Press978-1-139-48625-547Michael Faraday had a reply written, byGerrit Moll, asOn the Alleged Decline of Science in England(1831).cite book[[Richard Holmes (biographer)|Richard Holmes]]The Age of Wonder2008Pantheon Books978-0-375-42222-5437–40On the front of the Royal Society Babbage had no impact, with the bland election of thePrince Augustus Frederick, Duke of SussexDuke of Sussexto succeed Gilbert the same year. As a broad manifesto, on the other hand, hisDeclineled promptly to the formation in 1831 of theBritish Association for the Advancement of Science(BAAS).

TheMechanics' Magazinein 1831 identified as Declinarians the followers of Babbage. In an unsympathetic tone it pointed outDavid Brewsterwriting in theQuarterly Reviewas another leader; with the barb that both Babbage and Brewster had received public money.cite bookThe Mechanics' Magazine, Museum, Register, Journal, and Gazettehttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 20131831M. Salmon373–4

In the debate of the period on statistics (quadata collection) and what is nowstatistical inference, the BAAS in its Statistical Section (which owed something also to Whewell) opted for data collection. This Section was the sixth, established in 1833 with Babbage as chairman andJohn Elliot Drinkwateras secretary. The foundation of theStatistical Societyfollowed.cite book[[Mary Poovey]]A History of the Modern Fact: Problems of Knowledge in the Sciences of Wealth and Societyhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 201315 November 1998University of Chicago Press978-0-226-67526-8309cite bookDov M. GabbayJohn WoodsBritish Logic in the Nineteenth Centuryhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 201310 March 2008Elsevier978-0-08-055701-4164cite bookPatricia JonesPopulation Malthus1979Routledge and Kegan Paul0 7100 0266 1445Babbage was its public face, backed by Richard Jones andRobert Malthus.cite bookJames P. HendersonEarly Mathematical Economics: William Whewell and the British casehttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20131996Rowman & Littlefield978-0-8476-8201-033

heading.italics: On the Economy of Machinery and Manufactures

article.paragraph: File:Babbage - On the economy of machinery and manufactures, 1835 - 5864499.tifthumb''On the economy of machinery and manufactures'', 1835File:Babbage sign language.jpgthumbBabbage's notation for machine parts, explanation from ''On a method of expressing by signs the action of machinery'' (1827) of his "Mechanical Notation", invented for his own use in understanding the work on the difference engine, and an influence on the conception of the analytical enginecite bookMichael LingrenGlory and Failure: The Difference Engines of Johann Müller, Charles Babbage and Georg and Edvard Scheutzhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20131990MIT Press978-0-262-12146-054Babbage publishedOn the Economy of Machinery and Manufactures(1832), on the organisation of industrial production. It was an influential early work ofoperational research.ThoemmesBritish19CBabbage, Charles39John Rennie the Youngerin addressing theInstitute of Civil Engineerson manufacturing in 1846 mentioned mostly surveys in encyclopaedias, and Babbage's book was first an article in theEncyclopdia Metropolitana, the form in which Rennie noted it, in the company of related works byJohn Farey, Jr.,Peter Barlow (mathematician)Peter BarlowandAndrew Ure.cite book[[Charles Manby]]Minutes of the Proceedings of the Institute of Civil Engineershttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 2013184657FromAn essay on the general principles which regulate the application of machinery to manufactures and the mechanical arts(1827), which became theEncyclopdia Metropolitanaarticle of 1829, Babbage developed the schematic classification of machines that, combined with discussion of factories, made up the first part of the book. The second part considered the "domestic and political economy" of manufactures.cite bookM. LucertiniAna Millán GascaFernando NicolòTechnological Concepts and Mathematical Models in the Evolution of Modern Engineering Systemshttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20132004Springer978-3-7643-6940-830

The book sold well, and quickly went to a fourth edition (1836).cite bookMauro F. GuillénMauro F. GuillénModels of Management: Work, Authority, and Organization in a Comparative Perspectivehttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 201315 October 1994University of Chicago Press978-0-226-31036-7207Babbage represented his work as largely a result of actual observations in factories, British and abroad. It was not, in its first edition, intended to address deeper questions of political economy; the second (late 1832) did, with three further chapters including one onpiece rate.cite bookMaxine BergThe Machinery Question and the Making of Political Economy 1815–1848http://books.google.com/books?id22 April 20134 February 1982CUP Archive978-0-521-28759-3181The book also contained ideas on rational design in factories, andprofit sharing.cite bookBruce E. KaufmanThe Global Evolution of Industrial Relations: Events, Ideas and the IIRAhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20132004Academic Foundation978-81-7188-544-266
article.heading: "Babbage principle"
article.paragraph: InEconomy of Machinerywas described what is now called the "Babbage principle". It pointed out commercial advantages available with more carefuldivision of labour. As Babbage himself noted, it had already appeared in the work ofMelchiorre Gioiain 1815.cite bookJulio SeguraCarlos Rodríguez BraunAn Eponymous Dictionary of Economics: A Guide To Laws And Theorems Named After Economistshttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20132004Edward Elgar Publishing978-1-84542-360-513The term was introduced in 1974 byHarry Braverman.cite bookWorkhttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 201330 December 2011Polity978-0-7456-4678-739Related formulations are the "principle of multiples" ofPhilip Sargant Florence, and the "balance of processes".cite bookP. Sargant FlorenceThe Logic of British and American Industry: A Realistic Analysis of Economic Structure and Governmenthttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20131953Routledge978-0-415-31350-651cite bookThe Theory of the Growth of the Firm [Electronic book]http://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20131995Oxford University Press978-0-19-828977-768

What Babbage remarked is that skilled workers typically spend parts of their time performing tasks that are below their skill level. If the labour process can be divided among several workers, labour costs may be cut by assigning only high-skill tasks to high-cost workers, restricting other tasks to lower-paid workers.cite bookGiddens, AnthonyHeld, DavidClasses, Power and Conflict: Classical and Contemporary Debateshttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20131982University of California Press978-0-520-04627-6155He also pointed out that training or apprenticeship can be taken as fixed costs; but thatreturns to scaleare available by his approach of standardisation of tasks, therefore again favouring thefactory system.cite bookGuang-Zhen SunReadings in the Economics of the Division of Labor: The classical traditionhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20132005World Scientific978-981-270-127-510His view ofhuman capitalwas restricted to minimising the time period for recovery of training costs.cite bookPere Mir ArtiguesJosep Gonza ́lez CalvetFunds, Flows and Time: An Alternative Approach to the Microeconomic Analysis of Productive Activitieshttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 20132007Springer978-3-540-71291-672 note 15
article.heading: Publishing
article.paragraph: Another aspect of the work was its detailed breakdown of the cost structure of book publishing. Babbage took the unpopular line, from the publishers' perspective, of exposing the trade's profitability.cite bookJames A. SecordVictorian Sensation: The Extraordinary Publication, Reception, and Secret Authorship of Vestiges of the Natural History of Creationhttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20132000University of Chicago Press978-0-226-74410-052He went as far as to name the organisers of the trade's restrictive practices.cite bookMary PooveyMaking a Social Body: British Cultural Formation, 1830–1864http://books.google.com/books?id22 April 201315 November 1995University of Chicago Press978-0-226-67524-4193 note 43Twenty years later he attended a meeting hosted byJohn Chapman (publisher)John Chapmanto campaign against the Booksellers Association, still acartel.cite bookRosemary AshtonG. H. Lewes: An Unconventional Victorian2000Pimlico0-7126-6689-3128
article.heading: Influence
article.paragraph: It has been written that "whatArthur Young (writer)Arthur Youngwas to agriculture, Charles Babbage was to thefactory visitand machinery".Attributed to Richard Romano. In William J. Ashworth, ''Memory, Efficiency, and Symbolic Analysis: Charles Babbage, John Herschel, and the Industrial Mind'', Isis Vol. 87, No. 4 (Dec. 1996), pp. 629653, at p. 631. Published by: The University of Chicago Press on behalf of "The History of Science Society"Babbage's theories are said to have influenced the layout of the1851 Great Exhibition,cite bookPeterH HoffenbergAn Empire on Display: English, Indian, and Australian Exhibitions from the Crystal Palace to the Great Warhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 April 20132001University of California Press978-0-520-21891-8178and his views had a strong effect on his contemporaryGeorge Julius Poulett Scrope.cite bookMaxine BergThe Machinery Question and the Making of Political Economy 1815–1848http://books.google.com/books?id25 April 20134 February 1982CUP Archive978-0-521-28759-3127Karl Marxargued that the source of theproductivityof the factory system was exactly the combination of the division of labour with machinery, building onAdam Smith, Babbage and Ure.cite bookÁkos Róna-TasThe Great Surprise of the Small Transformation: The Demise of Communism and the Rise of the Private Sector of Hungaryhttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 20131997University of Michigan Press978-0-472-10795-720Where Marx picked up on Babbage and disagreed with Smith was on the motivation for division of labour by the manufacturer: as Babbage did, he wrote that it was for the sake ofProfit (accounting)profitability, rather than productivity, and identified an impact on the concept of atrade (occupation)trade.cite bookBen FineAlfredo Saad-FilhoMarco BoffoThe Elgar Companion to Marxist Economicshttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 20132012Edward Elgar Publishing978-1-78100-122-6190

John Ruskinwent further, to oppose completely what manufacturing in Babbage's sense stood for.cite bookSympathy of Things: Ruskin and the Ecology of Designhttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20132011V2_ publishing978-90-5662-827-752–3Babbage also affected the economic thinking ofJohn Stuart Mill.cite bookPatrice L. R. article.heading: Natural theology
article.paragraph: In 1837, responding to the series of eightBridgewater Treatises, Babbage published hisNinth Bridgewater Treatise, under the titleOn the Power, Wisdom and Goodness of God, as manifested in the Creation. In this work Babbage weighed in on the side ofuniformitarianismin a current debate.cite bookGenesis and Geology: A Study in the Relations of Scientific Thought, Natural Theology, and Social Opinion in Great Britain, 1790–1850http://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20131996Harvard University Press978-0-674-34481-5247He preferred the conception of creation in which a God-givennatural lawdominated, removing the need for continuous "contrivance".cite bookJohn G. TrapaniTruth matters: essays in honor of Jacques Maritainhttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20132004CUA Press978-0-9669226-6-0109

The book is a work ofnatural theology, and incorporates extracts from related correspondence of Herschel withCharles Lyell.Note I, indarwin-online.org.uk, ''Babbage, Charles. 1838. The Ninth Bridgewater Treatise. 2d edn. London: John Murray.''Babbage put forward the thesis that God had the omnipotence and foresight to create as a divine legislator. In this book, Babbage dealt with relating interpretations between science and religion; on the one hand, he insisted that"there exists no fatal collision between the words ofThe BibleScriptureand the facts of nature;"on the one hand, he wrote theBook of Genesiswas not meant to be read literally in relation to scientific terms. Against those who said these were in conflict, he wrote"that the contradiction they have imagined can have no real existence, and that whilst the testimony ofMosesremains unimpeached, we may also be permitted to confide in the testimony of our senses."Babbage,Ninth Bridgewater Treatise. Chapter V. Further View of the same Subject. The Victorian Web.

The Ninth Bridgewater Treatise was quoted extensively inVestiges of the Natural History of Creation.cite bookJames A. SecordVictorian Sensation: The Extraordinary Publication, Reception, and Secret Authorship of Vestiges of the Natural History of Creationhttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20132000University of Chicago Press978-0-226-74410-0107The parallel with Babbage's computing machines is made explicit, as allowing plausibility to the theory thattransmutation of speciescould be pre-programmed.cite bookRobert ChambersVestiges of the Natural History of Creation and Other Evolutionary Writingshttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 201315 August 1994University of Chicago Press978-0-226-10073-9xvi–xvii

I would ask any fair-minded mathematician to read Babbage's Ninth Bridgewater Treatise and compare it with the works of his contemporaries in England; and then ask himself whence came the peculiar conception of the nature of miracle which underlies Babbage's ideas of Singular Points on Curves (Chap, viii) from European Theology or Hindu Metaphysic? Oh! how the English clergy of that day hated Babbage's book!cite bookBoole, Mary EverestIndian Thought and Western Science in the Nineteenth CenturyCobham, E.M.; Dummer, E.S.Boole, Mary Everest "Collected Works"DanielLondon1931947–967http://books.google.com.au/books?id
article.heading: Religious views
article.paragraph: Babbage was raised in the Protestant form of the Christian faith, his family having inculcated in him an orthodox form of worship.s:Page:Passages from the Life of a Philosopher.djvu/24Passages from the Life of a Philosopher(1864), p. 8.He explained:Quote"My excellent mother taught me the usual forms of my daily and nightly prayer; and neither in my father nor my mother was there any mixture of bigotry and intolerance on the one hand, nor on the other of that unbecoming and familiar mode of addressing the Almighty which afterwards so much disgusted me in my youthful years."Babbage, (1864)Rejecting theAthanasian Creedas a "direct contradiction in terms", in his youth he looked toSamuel Clarke's works on religion, of whichBeing and Attributes of God(1704) exerted a particularly strong influence on him. Later in life, Babbage concluded that "the true value of the Christian religion rested, not on speculative theology, but on "those doctrines of kindness and benevolence which that religion claims and enforces, not merely in favour of man himself but of every creature susceptible of pain or of happiness.""Passages from the life of a philosopher" (1864), The Basis Of Virtue Is Truth, p. 404-405

In his autobiographyPassages from the Life of a Philosopher(1864), Babbage wrote a whole chaper on the topicreligion, where he identified three sources of divine knowledge:[Passages from the Life of a Philosopher https://archive.org/stream/passagesfromlif00babbgoog#page/n402/mode/2up](1864), p. 396

article.paragraph: He stated, on the basis of thedesign argument, that studying the works of nature had been the more appealing evidence, and the one which led him to actively profess theexistence of God.Smithsonian Institution. (1846).Annual report of the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution. Washington Government Pringting Office. Smithsonian Institution"Passages from the life of a philosopher" (1864), The Athanasian Creed , p. 403:"In the course of my inquiries, I met with the work upon the Trinity, by Dr. Samuel Clarke. This I carefully examined, and although very far from being satisfied, I ceased from further inquiry. This change arose probably from my having acquired the much more valuable work of the same author, on the Being and Attributes of God. This I studied, and felt that its doctrine was much more intelligible and satisfactory than that of the former work. I may now state, as the result of a long life spent in studying the works of the Creator, that I am satisfied they afford far more satisfactory and more convincing proofs of the existence of a supreme Being than any evidence transmitted through human testimony can possibly supply."Advocating for natural theology, he wrote:Quote"In the works of the Creator ever open to our examination, we possess a firm basis on which to raise the superstructure of an enlightened creed. The more man inquires into the laws which regulate the material universe, the more he is convinced that all its varied forms arise from the action of a few simple principles... The works of the Creator, ever present to our senses, give a living and perpetual testimony of his power and goodness far surpassing any evidence transmitted through human testimony. The testimony of man becomes fainter at every stage of transmission, whilst each new inquiry into the works of the Almighty gives to us more exalted views of his wisdom, his goodness, and his power."Babbage, (1864),''[https://archive.org/stream/passagesfromlif00babbgoog#page/n408/mode/2up Passages from the Life of a Philosopher]'' (1864), The Belief In The Creator From His Works, p. 396-402

LikeSamuel Vince, Babbage also wrote a defense of the belief in divinemiracles.Pickover, Clifford A. (2009).The Math Book: From Pythagoras to the 57th Dimension, 250 Milestones in the History of Mathematics.Sterling Publishing Company, Inc. p. 218Against objections previously posed byDavid Hume, Babbage advocated for the belief of divine agency, stating "we must not measure the credibility or incredibility of an event by the narrow sphere of our own experience, nor forget that there is a Divine energy which overrides what we familiarly call the laws of nature."Babbage, Charles. (1864) "Passages from the life of a philosopher": Appendix. "Miracles", p. 488He alluded to the limits of human experience, expressing: "all that we see in a miracle is an effect which is new to our observation, and whose cause is concealed. The cause may be beyond the sphere of our observation, and would be thus beyond the familiar sphere of nature; but this does not make the event a violation of any law of nature. The limits of man's observation lie within very narrow boundaries, and it would be arrogance to suppose that the reach of man's power is to form the limits of the natural world."
article.heading: Later life
article.paragraph: The British Association was consciously modelled on the Deutsche Naturforscher-Versammlung, founded in 1822.cite bookAndrew EdeLesley B. CormackA History of Science in Society: From the Scientific Revolution to the Presenthttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20132012University of Toronto Press978-1-4426-0452-0224It rejectedromantic scienceas well asmetaphysics, and started to entrench the divisions of science from literature, and professionals from amateurs.cite bookDaniel BrownThe Poetry of Victorian Scientists: Style, Science and Nonsensehttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 201331 January 2013Cambridge University Press978-1-107-02337-66Belonging as he did to the "Wattite" faction in the BAAS, represented in particular byJames Watt the younger, Babbage identified closely with industrialists. He wanted to go faster in the same directions, and had little time for the more gentlemanly component of its membership. Indeed, he subscribed to a version ofconjectural historythat placedindustrial societyas the culmination of human development (and shared this view with Herschel). A clash withRoderick Murchisonled in 1838 to his withdrawal from further involvement.cite bookDiscovering Water: James Watt, Henry Cavendish, and the Nineteenth Century 'Water Controversy'http://books.google.com/books?id1 May 20132004Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.978-0-7546-3177-4136–7cite bookIwan Rhys MorusBodies/Machineshttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20131 December 2002Berg978-1-85973-695-144At the end of the same year he sent in his resignation as Lucasian professor, walking away also from the Cambridge struggle with Whewell. His interests became more focussed, on computation andmetrology, and on international contacts.cite bookKevin C. KnoxFrom Newton to Hawking: A History of Cambridge University's Lucasian Professors of Mathematicshttp://books.google.com/books?id26 April 20136 November 2003Cambridge University Press978-0-521-66310-6287
article.heading: Metrology programme
article.paragraph: A project announced by Babbage was to tabulate allphysical constants(referred to as "constants of nature", a phrase in itself a neologism), and then to compile an encyclopaedic work of numerical information. He was a pioneer in the field of "absolute measurement".cite bookMario BiagioliThe Science studies readerhttp://books.google.com/books?id1 May 20131999Routledge, Chapman & Hall, Incorporated978-0-415-91868-8459–60His ideas followed on from those ofJohann Christian Poggendorff, and were mentioned toDavid BrewsterBrewsterin 1832. There were to be 19 categories of constants, andIan Hackingsees these as reflecting in part Babbage's "eccentric enthusiasms".cite bookIan HackingThe Taming of Chancehttp://books.google.com/books?id1 May 201331 August 1990Cambridge University Press978-0-521-38884-955–60Babbage's paperOn Tables of the Constants of Nature and Artwas reprinted by theSmithsonian Institutionin 1856, with an added note that the physical tables ofArnold Henry Guyot"will form a part of the important work proposed in this article".cite bookReport of the Board of Regentshttp://books.google.com/books?id1 May 20131857The Institution289–302

Exact measurement was also key to the development of machine tools. Here again Babbage is considered a pioneer, withHenry Maudslay,William Sellers, andJoseph Whitworth.cite bookDavid F NobleAmerica by Design: Science, Technology, and the Rise of Corporate Capitalism David F. Noblehttp://books.google.com/books?id8 May 20131 September 1979Oxford University Press978-0-19-502618-471

In 1838, Babbage invented thepilot (locomotive)pilot(also called a cow-catcher), the metal frame attached to the front of locomotives that clears the tracks of obstacles;cite bookLeeJohn A. N.International biographical dictionary of computer pioneers1995Taylor & Francis US60he also constructed adynamometer car.His eldest son,Benjamin Herschel Babbage, worked as an engineer for Brunel on the railways before emigrating to Australia in the 1850s.cite webhttp://www.asap.unimelb.edu.au/bsparcs/biogs/P000074b.htmBabbage, Benjamin HerschelBright Sparcs Biographical entry15 May 2008

article.heading: Cryptography
article.paragraph: Babbage achieved notable results incryptography, though this was still not known a century after his death.Letter frequencywas category 18 of Babbage's tabulation project.Joseph Henrylater defended interest in it, in the absence of the facts, as relevant to the management ofmovable type.

As early as 1845, Babbage had solved a cipher that had been posed as a challenge by his nephew Henry Hollier, and in the process, he made a discovery about ciphers that were based on Vigenre tables. Specifically, he realized that enciphering plain text with a keyword rendered the cipher text subject tomodular arithmetic.During theCrimean Warof the 1850s, Babbage broke Vigenre'sautokey cipheras well as the much weaker cipher that is calledVigenre ciphertoday.cite bookIntroduction to Cryptography: With Mathematical Foundations in Computer Implementationshttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20132011CRC Press978-1-4398-1763-6187His discovery was kept a military secret, and was not published. Credit for the result was instead given toFriedrich Kasiski, a Prussian infantry officer, who made the same discovery some years later.cite bookKahn, David L.The Codebreakers: The Story of Secret Writing1996ScribnerNew York978-0-684-83130-5However, in 1854, Babbage published the solution of a Vigenre cipher, which had been published previously in theJournal of the Society of Arts.See:J.H.B. article.heading: Public nuisances
article.paragraph: Babbage involved himself in well-publicised but unpopular campaigns against public nuisances. He once counted all the broken panes of glass of a factory, publishing in 1857 a "Table of the Relative Frequency of the Causes of Breakage of Plate Glass Windows": Of 464 broken panes, 14 were caused by "drunken men, women or boys".cite journalTable of the Relative Frequency of Occurrence of the Causes of Breaking of Plate Glass WindowsBabbage, CharlesMechanics Magazine18576682cite bookBabbage, CharlesThe Works of Charles BabbageV1989William PickeringLondon137Martin Campbell-Kelly1-85196-005-8cite bookhttp://books.google.com/?idThe Insurance cyclopaediaGoogle Books22 February 20111878

Babbage's distaste for commoners ("the Mob") included writing "Observations of Street Nuisances" in 1864, as well as tallying up 165 "nuisances" over a period of 80 days. He especially hatedbuskingstreet music, and in particular the music oforgan grinders, against whom he railed in various venues. The following quotation is typical:quote<arg name="It is difficult to estimate the misery inflicted upon thousands of persons, and the absolute pecuniary penalty imposed upon multitudes of intellectual workers by the loss of their time, destroyed by organ-grinders and other similar nuisances.''{{cite book | author">Campbell-Kelly, Martin; Babbage, Charles | title

Babbage was not alone in his campaign. A convert to the cause was the MPMichael Thomas Bass.cite bookKaren ChaseMichael LevensonThe Spectacle of Intimacy: A Public Life for the Victorian Familyhttp://books.google.com/books?id22 April 201315 August 2009Princeton University Press978-1-4008-3112-8151

In the 1860s, Babbage also took up the anti-Hoop rolling#British Empirehoop-rollingcampaign. He blamed hoop-rolling boys for driving their iron hoops under horses' legs, with the result that the rider is thrown and very often the horse breaks a leg.harvnbBabbage1864360Babbage achieved a certain notoriety in this matter, being denounced in debate in Commons in 1864 for "commencing a crusade against the popular game oftip-catand the trundling of hoops."Hansard's parliamentary debates. Parliament, Thomas Curson Hansard "Street Music (Metropolis) Bill "; V4, p471
article.heading: Computing pioneer

link.part: Part of Charles Babbage's difference engine (#1), assembled after his death by his son, Henry Prevost Babbage (18241918), using parts found in Charles' laboratory

article.paragraph: Babbage's machines were among the first mechanical computers. That they were not actually completed was largely because of funding problems and clashes of personality, most notably withGeorge Biddell AiryAiry, the Astronomer Royal.cite bookSwade, D.[[The Clockwork Brain]]Little Brown and CompanyLondon2000186

Babbage directed the building of some steam-powered machines that achieved some modest success, suggesting that calculations could be mechanised. For more than ten years he received government funding for his project, which amounted to 17,000, but eventually the Treasury lost confidence in him.cite bookGleick, J.[[The Information: A History, a Theory, a Flood]]Fourth EstateLondon2011104

While Babbage's machines were mechanical and unwieldy, their basic architecture was similar to a modern computer. The data and program memory were separated, operation was instruction-based, the control unit could make conditional jumps, and the machine had a separateInput/outputI/Ounit.
article.heading: Background on mathematical tables
article.paragraph: In Babbage's time, printedmathematical tableswere calculated byhuman computers, in other words by hand. They were central to navigation, science and engineering, as well as mathematics. Mistakes were known to occur in transcription as well as calculation.

At Cambridge, Babbage saw the fallibility of this process, and the opportunity of adding mechanisation into its management. His own account of his path towards mechanical computation references a particular occasion:

paragraph.extension: In 1812 he was sitting in his rooms in the Analytical Society looking at a table of logarithms, which he knew to be full of mistakes, when the idea occurred to him of computing all tabular functions by machinery. The French government had produced several tables by a new method. Three or four of their mathematicians decided how to compute the tables, half a dozen more broke down the operations into simple stages, and the work itself, which was restricted to addition and subtraction, was done by eighty computers who knew only these two arithmetical processes. Here, for the first time, mass production was applied to arithmetic, and Babbage was seized by the idea that the labours of the unskilled computers could be taken over completely by machinery which would be quicker and more reliable.B. V. Bowden,Faster than Thought, Pitman (1953), p. 8.

article.paragraph: There was another period, seven years later, when his interest was aroused by the issues around computation of mathematical tables. The French official initiative byGaspard de Prony, and its problems of implementation, were familiar to him. After theNapoleonic Warscame to a close, scientific contacts were renewed on the level of personal contact: in 1819Charles Blagdenwas in Paris looking into the printing of the stalled de Prony project, and lobbying for the support of the Royal Society. In works of the 1820s and 1830s, Babbage referred in detail to de Prony's project.cite bookMartin Campbell-KellyThe History of Mathematical Tables: From Sumer to Spreadsheetshttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 20132 October 2003Oxford University Press978-0-19-850841-0110cite bookCharles Coulston GillispieScience and Polity in France: The End of the Old Regimehttp://books.google.com/books?id19 April 201310 January 2009Princeton University Press978-1-4008-2461-8485
article.heading: Difference engine

link.part: TheScience Museum (London)Science Museum's Difference Engine No. 2, built from Babbage's design

article.paragraph: Babbage began in 1822 with what he called the difference engine, made to compute values ofpolynomial functions. It was created to calculate a series of values automatically. By using the method offinite differences, it was possible to avoid the need for multiplication and division.

For a prototype difference engine, Babbage brought inJoseph Clementto implement the design, in 1823. Clement worked to high standards, but hismachine toolswere particularly elaborate. Under the standard terms of business of the time, he could charge for their construction, and would also own them. He and Babbage fell out over costs around 1831.cite ODNB37291Clement, JosephAnitaMcConnell

Some parts of the prototype survive in theMuseum of the History of Science, Oxford.Cite journalDenisRoegelPrototype Fragments from Babbage's First Difference EngineIEEE Annals of the History of Computing3170–5April–June 2009210.1109/MAHC.2009.31{{inconsistent citations}}This prototype evolved into the "first difference engine." It remained unfinished and the finished portion is located at the Science Museum in London. This first difference engine would have been composed of around 25,000 parts, weigh fifteenshort tontons(13,600 kg), and would have beenConvert8ftm1ontall. Although Babbage received ample funding for the project, it was never completed. He later (18471849) produced detailed drawings for an improved version,"Difference Engine No. 2", but did not receive funding from the British government. His design was finally constructed in 19891991, using his plans and 19th century manufacturing tolerances. It performed its first calculation at the London Science Museum, returning results to 31 digits.

Nine years later, the Science Museum completed thecomputer printerprinterBabbage had designed for the difference engine.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/710950.stmSCI/TECH | Babbage printer finally runsBBC News13 April 200027 April 2012
article.heading: Completed models

preblock.preline: The London Science Museum has constructed two Difference Engines according to Babbage's plans for the Difference Engine No 2. One is owned by the museum. The other, owned by the technology multimillionaireNathan Myhrvold, went on exhibition at theComputer History Museumcite webhttp://www.computerhistory.org/babbage/Overview – The Babbage EngineComputer History Museum29 January 2009inMountain View, Californiaon 10 May 2008.cite newsShielsMaggieVictorian 'supercomputer' is rebornhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7391593.stm11 May 2008BBC News10 May 2008The two models that have been constructed are not replicas; Myhrvold's engine is the first design by Babbage, and the London Science Museum's is a later model.

article.heading: Analytical Engine
article.paragraph: mainAnalytical EngineAfter the attempt at making the first difference engine fell through, Babbage worked to design a more complex machine called theAnalytical Engine. He hired C. G. Jarvis, who had previously worked for Clement as a draughtsman.cite bookBruce CollierJames MacLachlanCharles Babbage: And the Engines of Perfectionhttp://books.google.com/books?id20 April 201328 September 2000Oxford University Press978-0-19-514287-765The Analytical Engine marks the transition from mechanised arithmetic to fully-fledged general purpose computation. It is largely on it that Babbage's standing as computer pioneer rests.cite webThe Baggage Enginehttp://www.computerhistory.org/babbage/Computer History Museum6 March 2013

The major innovation was that the Analytical Engine was to be programmed usingpunched cards: the Engine was intended to use loops ofJacquard loomJacquard'spunched cards to control a mechanical calculator, which could use as input the results of preceding computations.cite bookCeruzziPaulComputing: A Concise History2012Smithsonian InstitutionUnited States97802625176767–8The machine was also intended to employ several features subsequently used in modern computers, including sequential control, branching and looping. It would have been the first mechanical device to be, in principle,Turing-complete. The Engine was not a single physical machine, but rather a succession of designs that Babbage tinkered with until his death in 1871.File:Opening George III museum.jpgthumbPart of the Analytical Engine on display, in 1843, left of centre in this engraving of theKing George III Museum
article.heading: Ada Lovelace and Italian followers
article.paragraph: Ada Lovelacecorresponded with him during his development of the Analytical Engine. She is credited with developing an algorithm for the Analytical Engine to calculate a sequence ofBernoulli numbers. Although there is disagreement over how much of the ideas were Lovelace's own, she is often described as the firstprogrammercomputer programmer.cite journalFuegi J, Francis JLovelace & Babbage and the creation of the 1843 'notes'Annals of the History of Computing25416–26October–December 200310.1109/MAHC.2003.1253887See pages 19, 25She also translated and wrote literature supporting the project. Babbage visitedTurinin 1840 at the invitation ofGiovanni Plana. In 1842Charles Wheatstoneapproached Lovelace to translate a paper ofLuigi Menabrea, who had taken notes of Babbage's Turin talks; and Babbage asked her to add something of her own.Fortunato Prandiwho acted as interpreter in Turin was an Italian exile and follower ofGiuseppe Mazzini.cite bookBenjamin WoolleyThe Bride of Science1999Macmillan0-333-72436-4258–60, 338
article.heading: Swedish followers
article.paragraph: Per Georg Scheutzwrote about the difference engine in 1830, and experimented in automated computation. After 1834 and Lardner'sEdinburgh Reviewarticle he set up a project of his own, doubting whether Babbage's initial plan could be carried out. This he pushed through with his son, Edvard Scheutz.cite bookMichael LingrenGlory and Failure: The Difference Engines of Johann Müller, Charles Babbage and Georg and Edvard Scheutzhttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 20131990MIT Press978-0-262-12146-098–112Another Swedish engine was that ofMartin Wiberg(1860).cite bookI. Grattan-GuinnessCompanion encyclopedia of the history and philosophy of the mathematical scienceshttp://books.google.com/books?id27 April 20131 September 2003JHU Press978-0-8018-7396-6698
article.heading: Legacy
article.paragraph:
In 2011, researchers in Britain embarked on a multimillion-pound project, "Plan 28", to construct Babbage's Analytical Engine. Since Babbage's plans were continually being refined and were never completed, they intended to engage the public in the project andcrowdsourcingcrowd-sourcethe analysis of what should be built.cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/08/science/computer-experts-building-1830s-babbage-analytical-engine.html?_rIt Started Digital Wheels TurningNew York Times10 November 2011It would have the equivalent of 675 bytes of memory, and run at a clock speed of about 7 Hz. They hope to complete it by the 150th anniversary of Babbage's death, in 2021.cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-15001514 Babbage Analytical Engine designs to be digitised BBC News
21 September 2011 19 March 2012

Advances inmicroelectromechanical systemMEMsandnanotechnologyhave led to recent high-tech experiments in mechanical computation. The benefits suggested include operation in high radiation or high temperature environments.cite webhttp://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0WVI/is_1999_Oct_11/ai_56912203/printElectronics Times: Micro-machines are fit for spaceFindarticles.com11 October 199929 January 2009These modern versions of mechanical computation were highlighted inThe Economistin its special "end of the millennium" black cover issue in an article entitled "Babbage's Last Laugh".cite newsBabbage's Last LaughThe Economist9 September 1999http://www.economist.com/node/324654?story_id

article.paragraph: On 25 July 1814, Babbage married Georgiana Whitmore at St. Michael's Church inTeignmouth, Devon; her sister Louisa married Edward Ryan.The couple lived atDudmaston Hall,cite webhttp://www.visitbritain.co.uk/Attraction/Bridgnorth/Historic-House-or-Palace/157092/Dudmaston-Hall.htmAttraction information for Dudmaston HallVisitBritain29 January 2009Shropshire (where Babbage engineered the central heating system), before moving to 5 Devonshire Street, Portland Place, London.

Charles and Georgiana had eight children,cite webhttp://www.bavidge.co.uk/Babbage%20Family%20Tree%202005,%20InternetTree/wc03/wc03_074.htmBabbage Family Tree 2005Valerie Bavidge-Richardson9 February 2013http://web.archive.org/web/20071013194355/http://bavidge.co.uk/Babbage%20Family%20Tree%202005,%20InternetTree/wc03/wc03_074.htm13 October 2007

Charles' wife Georgiana died inWorcesteron 1 September 1827, the same year as his father, their second son (also named Charles) and their newborn son Alexander.
